image.altText: Plane crashed into bushes

items.synopsis: One person has been seriously injured after a light plane crash near Derby.

title.children: Authorities investigating light plane crash in WA's far north

image.altText: Australian currency is seen next to a wages graph

items.synopsis: The stock market is a few percentage points away from an all-time high because some of Australia's biggest corporations are making record profits. But Australian households are under pressure, writes David Taylor.

title.children: The Reserve Bank has pointed directly to the elephant in the room

image.altText: David Warner gets off the team bus as rain falls at Edgbaston ahead of the last day of the first Ashes Test.

items.synopsis: The Ashes first Test is set for a grandstand finish on day five, but rain is hovering about Birmingham to delay play. Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Stage set for dramatic finale to first Ashes Test

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We've been told there will be no play until at least lunch, which will be taken early at 9:30pm AEST. So there's a bit of time to waste before the action gets underway.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No play until at least 10:10pm AEST

children.content: We've been told there will be no play until at least lunch, which will be taken early at 9:30pm AEST.
So there's a bit of time to waste before the action gets underway.

image.altText: Collins gestures with one hand while speaking at the despatch box in the House of Representatives.

items.synopsis: The federal government has left open the option of pursuing housing options that will be met with less resistance, after failing to pass its signature $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund.

title.children: Housing minister won't rule out dumping signature $10b fund in favour of easier paths to building housing

image.altText: Josh makes a peace sign while wearing formal attire

items.synopsis: Cracks in the National Disability Insurance Scheme contributed to the death of a 24-year-old man who died after being handcuffed at Perth's underground train station, according to a disability advocate.

title.children: 'Josh didn't have support': Gaps in NDIS contributed to death of man at train station, disability advocate says

image.altText: Outside shot of a cream and brick art deco building with white columns, the words court house on the facade

items.synopsis: A WA couple has been refused bail after allegedly stealing a tractor, erratically driving 80km along a Victorian highway and crashing into the fence of Puckapunyal Army Base.

title.children: WA couple allegedly steals $150k tractor, crashes into army base fence

image.altText: Thorpe holds a phone up for Hargraves as he reads a message from it to journalists.

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe gives her full support to the No case for the Voice to Parliament, following what she called a breakdown in negotiations with government on Indigenous justice.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe announces she will be backing No campaign against Indigenous Voice

image.altText: A western man extends his hand and walks towards a taller Chinese man in a conference room

items.synopsis: Despite the first visit to Beijing of a US secretary of state in almost five years, there were signs that China was less than enthusiastic about welcoming Antony Blinken. Here are the key takeaways from the two-day visit.

title.children: 'Xi wanted the upper hand': Five takeaways from the China-US talks in Beijing

image.altText: A large pink fish swims underwater.

items.synopsis: In a partial backdown over contentious demersal fishing bans, the government will allow charter operators to catch and cook certain species on their boats.

title.children: Fishing charter operators split on WA government's proposed 'catch and cook' scheme

image.altText: Jacqui Lambie and Glenn Kolomeitz stand in front of microphones at a press conference inside Parliament House

items.synopsis: Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie has requested the International Criminal Court investigate senior Australian Defence Force commanders over their knowledge of alleged war crimes in Afghanistan.

title.children: Lambie demands The Hague investigate Australian top brass over knowledge of war crimes

image.altText: Aerial shot lookingn straight down at big battery project under construction

items.synopsis: One of the world's biggest renewable energy providers is increasing its stakes in Australia after receiving approval to build a multi-billion-dollar battery in Western Australia's coal heartlands.

title.children: French green energy giant doubles down on Australia with mega WA battery

image.altText: A composite of Hamish Harding and the submersive which is lost near the Titanic wreck.

items.synopsis: Deep in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, a search is underway for a submersible that was carrying five people when it disappeared on an expedition to the wreckage of the Titanic.

title.children: Frantic search as Titanic submersible disappears underwater with five people and 96 hours' oxygen

image.altText: A photo of a white submersible under water.

items.synopsis: A submersible has gone missing while on a dive to the wreck of the Titanic in the Atlantic Ocean. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: A spot on this Titanic submersible expedition costs more than $300,000 — here's what we know about it

image.altText: Robert Hall in a suit and tie smiling

items.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a cyclist hit by a four-wheel drive on an SA highway hears a recommendation to annually re-test the driver — who was visually impaired after a stroke — was ignored.

title.children: 'Red flags' about driver's visual impairment ignored before cyclist fatally hit, inquest told

image.altText: A dark skinned man with a baseball cap and a serious expression

items.synopsis: At a youth centre in Perth's eastern suburbs where Cassius Turvey could often be found, a place that helps stop children from falling through the cracks, the teenager's absence is still being sorely felt.

title.children: Ray Tanielu knew Cassius Turvey and his friends well. Eight months on from the teenager's death, he's seen a change

image.altText: A trial field of cannabis growing in Queensland.

items.synopsis: The Legalise Cannabis party says the move to reform cannabis legislation will help shift Australians out of the criminal justice system.

title.children: Bills introduced in three states to legalise cannabis for personal use

image.altText: A male security guard stands with his back to the camera as shoppers walk past.

items.synopsis: More private security guards are patrolling public places like schools, shopping strips and libraries. Some find the trend reassuring, while others say it's alarming.

title.children: Why are Australians turning to private security guards in record numbers?

image.altText: Indigenous rock art painting of hands and a kookaburra in a cave at Carnarvon Gorge

items.synopsis: Indigenous leaders and local rangers say the lengths people will go to for the perfect photograph at Carnarvon Gorge are disrespectful and unlawful.

title.children: Social media influencers ruining ancient Indigenous art at Carnarvon Gorge, rangers say

image.altText: A person walking a dog down an outdoor path from behind.

items.synopsis: Beyond the obvious unsightliness and the likelihood of making unwanted contact with dog poo, there are other important reasons to pick up after dogs, writes Melissa Starling.

title.children: Is leaving dog poo in the street really so bad? The science says it's even worse than you think

image.altText: A woman in a coma lies in a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Kylee Enwright is back in her home community after falling and hitting her head 10 hours into a Thailand holiday with her husband.

title.children: NSW woman flown home from Thailand after 'terrible' holiday accident

image.altText: Justin Kane Millington

items.synopsis: A rape victim survivor has told her perpetrator that she still suffers flashbacks and is "terrified" of being alone around men.

title.children: Victim survivor lives in 'constant fear' nearly three years after Newcastle rape

image.altText: A composite picture with portraits of MP Cindy McLeish and Premier Daniel Andrews.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews refuses to apologise to Liberal MP Cindy McLeish after being accused of referring to her as a "half-wit grub" during a rowdy parliamentary sitting.

title.children: Victorian premier refuses to apologise to female Liberal MP over 'half-wit grub' comment

image.altText: Do Kwon, a Korean man with short hair wearing a blue shirt, in a video still.

items.synopsis: Authorities in Montenegro say Do Kwon, who is wanted on allegations of fraud and financial crimes, tried to fly to Dubai using a fake Costa Rican passport.

title.children: Founder of cryptocurrency firm Terraform Labs imprisoned for forging documents

image.altText: A still image from the original film shows a robot woman with waves over her head in black and white.

items.synopsis: Universal Studious cancels a major production for TV series Metropolis that was set to employ hundreds, citing fallout from the US writers' strike

title.children: Universal Studios pulls the plug on major TV series Metropolis to be filmed in Melbourne

image.altText: Frost builds up on a fence post

items.synopsis: Winter solstice is only a few days away but it doesn't mark the beginning of winter in Australia. It also doesn't mark the middle of winter or even the coldest day of the year.

title.children: Thursday will be the shortest day of the year — here's why that might seem out of sync with the seasons

image.altText: A police officer in uniform and a figure in a full-body white forensics suit stand by a police screen.

items.synopsis: Kenan Dowden-Carlisle, who previously pleaded guilty to stabbing Jordan Powell in broad daylight in 2021, tells a court he mistakenly believed Mr Powell took his satchel containing his drugs.

title.children: Mistaken belief satchel containing drugs was stolen prompted Garema Place stabbing murder, court hears

image.altText: A drone photo of a river winding through lush greenery, including a small island. The sky is blue.

items.synopsis: The NT government paid consulting fees of almost $150,000 to a lobbying firm to try to "influence" the Commonwealth government to support a gas-based manufacturing hub on Darwin Harbour, FOI documents show.

title.children: FOI shows NT government enlisted lobbying firm to get federal support for $1.5 billion project

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: Minutes from this month's RBA board meeting show interest rates were almost kept steady this month, but it wants to slow employment and economic growth.

title.children: The Reserve Bank almost left interest rates on hold this month, but it also wants the unemployment rate to rise

image.altText: a sign that reads Norseman and esperance

items.synopsis: A 33-year-old man has died after two trucks collided near the Goldfields town of Widgiemooltha, about 600 kilometres east of Perth on Tuesday morning.

title.children: Truck driver dies in collision with road train near Widgiemooltha

image.altText: Baby Jarrod at time of second visit to Caboolture hospital in October 2022. The child has a rash around his mouth and face

items.synopsis: Baby Jarrod was in "absolute agony" when his parents took him to the emergency department two days in a row. He only received a diagnosis when his father called in Ryan's Rule.

title.children: Baby in 'absolute agony' turned away days after assurances hospital was providing best possible care

image.altText: A composite image of two men and a woman, separated by paper tears.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, more than 46,000 clients under state control are prevented by law from being identified, but there are growing calls for change. Some say gag laws that were designed to protect vulnerable people are shielding the agencies involved from scrutiny.

title.children: Memories sent to the tip, refused money for Christmas — and all by order of the state

image.altText: A powhiri ceremony at the marae of the Te Papa museum in Wellington.

items.synopsis: Snatched by grave robbers or traded by settlers as macabre curiosities, the remains of New Zealand's Indigenous people are slowly being brought home after centuries overseas.

title.children: 'Like a crime ring': New Zealand brings home stolen, traded Indigenous remains
